original_title: Glow Plug Turned Metal-Capable 3D Printer Hotend
original_content:
At this point, most readers will be familiar with fused deposition modeling (FDM) 3D printers, and how a plastic filament is pushed through a heater and deposited as liquid through a nozzle. Most of us also know that there are a huge variety of materials that can be FDM printed, but theres one which perhaps evades us: you cant load a spool of metal wire into your printer and print in metal, or at least you cant yet. Its something [Rotoforge] is working on, with a project to make a hot end that can melt metal. Their starting point is a ceramic diesel engine glow plug, from which they expect 1300 C (2372 F).
The video below the break deals with the process of converting the glow plug, which mostly means stripping off the metal parts which make it a glow plug, and then delicately EDM drilling a hole through its ceramic tip. The video is well worth a watch for the in-depth examination of how they evolved the means to do this.
Sadly they arent at the point of printing metal with this thing, but we think the current progress is impressive enough to have a good chance of working. Definitely one to watch.
Previous metal 3D printers weve featured have often used a MIG welder.


Thanks [theFinn] for the tip!
title: 金属を溶かして印刷するための新技術開発中
body: 3Dプリンタで金属を印刷する方法について新技術が進化中。[Rotoforge]が金属を溶かすホットエンドを開発中。セラミックディーゼルエンジンのグロープラグから始め、進展中。
titles: 金属を溶かして印刷するための新技術開発中
金属糸を使用した3Dプリンターの可能性に挑戦
金属印刷への革新的なアプローチ
セラミックディーゼルエンジンプラグを使用した金属印刷の試み
金属印刷技術の進化に期待
